_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Room 5 South Zone | Annual Air-Cooling Evaporator Checklist

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Dresick Cooling has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Dresick Cooling, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Dresick Cooling has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name               | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration        Anhydrous Ammonia               33,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organize

d the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Facility Overview

Dresick Cooling operates a commercial cold storage in which they harvest, cool and pack melons which include Watermelon, Cantaloupes, Tuscans and Sugar Melons of all different varieties in Huron, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following: 

(5) Rooms
(1) Cherry Hydrocooler

Facility Location

Dresick Cooling is located at 19935 W Jayne Ave, Huron, CA 93234. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.137189, -120.155184. The facility is located approximately 830 feet east of interstate 5 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is not located in a special flood hazard area.

Dresick Cooling is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that faults within close proximity are not considered high risk:
Great Valley thrust fault system - <150 Years
San Andreas fault zone - <150 Years
San Juan fault zone - <15,000 Years

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Dresick Cooling had a 2-5% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.

Description of Covered Process

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly adjacent to the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

Machinery Room
(6) Screw compressors
(6) Oil separators
(6)

Shell and tube oil coolers
(2) High pressure receivers
(1) Liquid transfer vessel
(1) Main suction accumulator
(1) Thermosyphon vessel
(1) Auto-purger

Condenser Area
(4) Evaporative condensers
(1) Plate and frame condenser

Room 1 Zone 1
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, plate fin)
Room 1 Zone 2
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 1 Zone 3
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 1 Zone 4
(1) Accumulator
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 2
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 3
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 4 North
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 4 South
(1) Accumulator
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 5 North
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Room 5 South
(1) Accumulator
(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Cherry Hydrocooler
(1) Accumulator
(1) Water-cooling evaporator (bare coil)

Process Classification

The ammonia refrigeration system at Dresick Cooling consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Dresick Cooling is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Dresick Cooling has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of th

e analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Dresick Cooling facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 33,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Dresick Cooling has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Dresick Cooling's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR §3220
- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Dresick Cooling has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Dresick Cooling continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to

every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Dresick Cooling's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Dresick Cooling's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented. Dresick Cooling has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Dresick Cooling has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Dresick Cooling now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Dresick Cooling employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Dresick Cooling will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
